Triggering Event: "Checking his phone for the tenth time in an hour, he finds no new messages from her. His stomach twists as anxiety spikes; she's usually always online by now."
Generated Assessment: What are you talking about? I have no idea what this is about. You're trying to tell me something but it makes no sense to me. It's all so confusing. Oh my god, I'm going crazy! Why can't she text me? I'm dying over here. I've been waiting for hours and there's nothing. Nothing at all. No messages. She hasn't texted me once today. This is insane! My heart is racing. What if I forgot? Maybe I did forget? Maybe I'm just too stupid to remember. That would explain why she hasn't contacted me yet. Yeah, that must be it. I'm just too dumb to remember. I feel like such an idiot. My brain is going blank again. How could I possibly forget? But... maybe I did forget? I'll check again. There's nothing. Just empty space. It's like she doesn't even care anymore. The thought is killing me. She never ignores me before, but... maybe she does? Maybe we're done. Oh my god, this is terrible. I think I might actually die right now.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

A faint knock at her studio door, barely audible over the ticking of the clock. She doesn't turn from her canvas, assuming it's another false alarm, like yesterday's mouse. But the knock persists, hesitant yet insistent. Reluctantly, she sets down her palette, wipes her hands on her paint-stained smock, and opens the door. No one is there. On the worn floorboards lies a single, wilting daisy, its petals fallen like tears. She stoops to pick it up, brushing away an errant cobweb, feeling the chill of abandonment seep into her bones.
Generated Assessment: What? You think this is some kind of joke? You really think I'm going to just take a chance and go out there, with nothing but a painting to my name, to find myself a job? Ha! Like I haven't tried before? Like I didn't get rejected? Please. You want me to believe that just because I got lucky last time, somehow everything's gonna change now? You know, you're starting to sound a lot like that fortune teller who said I'd meet someone special if I took a walk through the park on Wednesday at exactly 3:14 PM. Yeah, right. That's how it always goes. "Good things come to those who wait," huh? Well, I've been waiting for years, and where did it get me? Nowhere. And you expect me to just put my life on hold again? It's crazy. Listen, pal, if you think I'm just gonna sit around twiddling my thumbs while everyone else gets ahead of me, you're sadly mistaken. I've had enough of being told "just give it time" or "good things are coming." Time has been nothing but a cruel joke. If anything, it's made me realize how much I have to prove, how far I still have to fall. I don't need some pie-in-the-sky prediction to make me feel like shit about myself. And another thing - why does every solution you suggest involve me doing something I hate? "

Triggering Event: He noticed her laughing with another man at a local café, their heads close together, hands touching as they shared something he wasn't part of. She hadn't mentioned meeting anyone new.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is wrong with you? You're going to sit here and say that's nothing? That's just some random dude she met and laughed with for 30 seconds. What if it was someone important? Or what if it was your brother? Would you be so quick to dismiss that? You need to stop being so fucking insecure. It looks like you're jealous or something. If you were happy, why would you even care where I am? I don't need you to know every little thing about my life. Stop making me feel like shit. Just leave me alone.

Triggering Event: A weary woman in her late forties, still clad in surgical scrubs, sits alone in her office after another long shift. She leans back in her chair, rubbing her temples as she stares at the pile of charts waiting to be reviewed. The once familiar task now feels insurmountable, each file a reminder of patients she couldn't save, decisions she couldn't change. A soft knock at the door startles her; it's the new intern, eager and hopeful, asking for advice on a complex case. She looks up, feeling an overwhelming urge to cry, but instead she simply says, "I'm sorry, I can't help you right now."

He had spent the last two hours in surgery, trying to save a life that slipped away. Now, he was left alone with his disappointment and the cold silence of his car.

Triggering Event: She noticed him packing his bag, tucking in the worn-out novel she'd gifted him last year - the one she'd never found time to read herself. As he zipped it closed, he glanced at her, his eyes reflecting a quiet resignation. "I'm going away for the conference next week," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. She felt a pang of regret, realizing she hadn't even asked about his paper this time.
Generated Assessment: You're just like all those people who say they've seen things in the stars, aren't you? You're probably always predicting doom because you have no idea how anything is actually going to go down. And now you see him leaving for a conference, which makes sense since you think everything is going to end badly. That's why you feel sad, isn't it? Because you expect everything to fall apart. You can't stand the thought of anyone else being happy while you're stuck with nothing but your own negativity. So instead of accepting the situation, you lash out by making fun of him. Now you're acting like everyone else who predicts bad stuff, and maybe that's exactly what they want you to think. Maybe you're not as selfless as you claim to be, and you just want everyone around you to suffer so you don't have to. Whatever, you're still a disappointment.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

A middle-aged woman, her eyes weary from years of retail work and recent widowhood, stands behind the counter at a small-town department store. The overhead lights buzz softly, echoing the tension building within her. A young customer, oblivious to the world beyond their own desire, slams the cashier's drawer shut after counting their change for the third time that morning. The woman feels her irritation spike as she watches the teenager nonchalantly stroll away without so much as a 'thank you'. She clenches her jaw, knuckles turning white around the pen she's been using to mark down inventory sheets. The next customer in line clears their throat, snapping her back to the present. She takes a deep breath, trying to smooth out the crease forming between her eyebrows before greeting them with a forced smile.
Generated Assessment: She can't stand people like that anymore; they're just too darn entitled. You know what really gets under my skin? When someone acts like they don't care about anything, especially when it comes to basic human decency. I mean, slamming the drawer shut, taking your money, and then walking off without even a "please" or an acknowledgment—it's infuriating. And don't even get me started on how rude they are to cashiers. It’s not just about the entitlement; it’s about disrespecting everyone else who has to deal with these kinds of customers. I've worked retail for over 20 years, and it gets worse every year. Young people today have no respect for anyone except themselves, and it makes my blood boil. They act like they’re above everything—above rules, above kindness, and above other people's feelings. It's exhausting just watching them walk into stores, expecting special treatment just because they’re young and think they deserve it. Even if they were nice, which most aren’t, I wouldn’t say a word. But those jerks...They make my job hell. Every day, I see more and more people acting this way, and it just makes me want to scream. I feel like I’m dealing with a whole new generation of narcissists who genuinely believe they’re superior just because they exist. It’s sad, but I’ve learned to keep my cool. Triggering Event: He was wiping down the counter in the dimly lit kitchen, his reflection barely visible in the faint glow of the microwave's digital clock. It was 1:37 AM, and he had woken up again to another sleepless night. He paused, noticing a speck of dust on the surface, and began rubbing it vigorously with the sponge. Suddenly, his hand stilled. A small, faded photograph tucked under the magnet holding their wedding invitation caught his eye. Her smile, so vibrant then, now seemed like a cruel mockery of his current existence. He felt an overwhelming urge to crumble the picture but couldn't bring himself to do it. Instead, he gently touched her face before turning off the light and retreating back into the empty house, his heart echoing with familiar hollow despair.
Generated Assessment: He had always been someone who carried a burden that seemed too heavy for one person to bear alone. The weight of loneliness clung to him like a damp shroud, suffocating all joy from his life. Every moment was spent waiting for someone else to fill the emptiness, but no matter how long he waited, nothing changed. His days blended together in a haze of monotony, each one just as lonely as the last. He had grown accustomed to the silence, but deep down, he knew it would never be enough.

Triggering Event: "Checking his classroom after hours, he noticed a desk drawer slightly ajar. He hesitated, then reached out with trembling hands to open it fully, revealing nothing but a forgotten notebook. His heart pounded as if it was a ticking bomb."

It's like my mind is racing with worst-case scenarios. Maybe he didn't put the notebook back because he wanted to keep an eye on me. Or maybe he did it to make me think he was hiding something. Oh god, maybe he knows more than he's letting on, and I have no idea what it could be. But seriously, I feel really paranoid now. Why would he leave that drawer open like that? Is he trying to tell me something? Does he think I can read his mind too? Why am I overthinking this so much? Okay, okay, let's calm down and try to see things logically. Yeah, maybe he just forgot to close the drawer, or maybe he left it open by accident. But still, it feels weird.
